APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 145 (1996) 141-153 Selective C-alkylation of phenol with methanol over catalysts derived from copper-aluminium hydrotalcite-like compounds S. Velu, C.S. Swamy Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras-600 036, India Received 11 December 1995; revised 19 March 1996; accepted 20 March 1996 Abstract Copper aluminium hydrotalcites (CuA1-HT) with a Cu/A1 atomic ratio of 2, 3 and 4 (CuA1 2.0-HT, CuA1 3.0-HT, CuA1 4.0-HT) were synthesised by the coprecipitation method using a mixture of NaOH/NazCO3 as precipitant. The pure crystalline hydrotalcite (HT) phase was detected by X-ray diffraction when the copper-aluminium hydrotalcite was prepared without ageing (CuAI 3.0-WAHT). Vapour phase alkylation of phenol with methanol was carried out over CuA1-HT calcined at 450/8 h in air (CuA1-CHT). The activity and selectivity of these catalysts were compared with those of magnesium-aluminium calcined hydrotalcites (MgAI 4.0-CHT) from our earlier report. MgA1 4.0-CHT showed higher selectivity for 2,6-xylenol whereas CuA1-CHT was selective for o-cresol. Among the CuA1-CHT studied, CuA1 3.0-CHT showed higher phenol conversion at low temperatures (250-350). The catalyst derived from pure copper-aluminium hydrotalcite (CuA1 3.0-WACHT) showed lowest phenol conversion compared to other copper based catalysts obtained from a mixture of HT and malachite phases. The selectivity for o-cresol decreased in the order CuA1 3.0-CHT > CuAI 2.0-CHT > CuAI 3.0- WACHT= CuA1 4.0-CHT > MgA1 4.0-CHT at low phenol conversion levels (15-20%). A suitable reaction pathway for the alkylation of phenol with methanol over these catalysts has been proposed after a careful examination of the reaction sequence. The selective C-alkylation to give o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol over CuA1-CHT could be attributed to the higher acidity of these catalysts as evidenced by the higher cyclohexanol dehydration activity. Swamy/Applied Catalysis A: General 145 (1996) 141-153 1. Introduction In recent years, there is an increasing interest for the synthesis of alkyl phenols especially o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol because of their importance as intermediates for the synthesis of a variety of resins, herbicides, insecticides and other important chemicals [1,2]. For example, epoxy cresol novolac (ECN) and polyphenylene oxide (PPO) used in the electronic industries and automobile industries are derived from o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol, respectively [3]. A wide variety of catalysts such as ~/-alumina, silica-alumina, metallic sulphates, phosphates, ALPOs, SAPOs, zeolites, acidic and basic oxides have been em- ployed for this reaction [4-11]. However, they produce a mixture of O- and C-alkylated products. Moreover, most of these catalysts exhibit unsatisfactory stability with time on stream due to coking from phenol or methanol [4,5,8]. Since, the alkylation of phenol with methanol is essentially an acid-base reaction, the product selectivity depends on the catalyst acidity and basicity. It has been found that catalysts with strong acidic sites favour O-alkylation while weak acidic sites or strong basic sites favour C-alkylation [10]. On the other hand, Tliemat-Manzalji et al. [12] and Marczewski et al. [7] have claimed that weak acidic sites favour C-alkylation. Recently, we have found [13] that thermally activated magnesium-aluminium hydrotalcites are more active and selective catalysts for the synthesis of 2,6-xylenol compared to either "y-Al203 or MgO. Hydrotalcites (HT) are a class of layered materials of current interest. They consist of positively charged brucite (Mg(OH)2)-like layers interspersed with hydrated anions in the interlayer. They are represented by the general formula, (M(II)l_xM(III)x(OH)2]n- A~/n. yH20, where, M(II) and M(III) are divalent and trivalent cations such as Mg2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+ and A13+, Fe3+, Cr3+ respectively, An- is the interlayer anion such as CI-, NO~, CO~ etc. and x = 0.1-0.33 [13-15]. Thermal calcination of these materials around 450 results in the formation of highly active mixed metallic oxides which are found to be promising base catalysts [16-19]. We have been interested in studying the effect of isomorphous substitution of Mg2+ by other divalent transition metal ions in the HT framework on the phenol conversion and product selectivity and to correlate their catalytic performance with acid-base properties as determined by the decomposition of 2-methyl-3- butyne-2-ol (MBOH) and cyclohexanol [20]. In this paper, we report our results on the alkylation of phenol with methanol over copper-aluminium calcined hydrotalcites with Cu/AI atomic ratio 2, 3, 4 for the first time. Since the copper containing hydrotalcites are always mixed with other phases such as malachite, attempts have been made to synthesis a pure copper-aluminium hydrotalcite precursor and the catalytic performance for the title reaction has been compared with that of other copper-aluminium and magnesium-aluminium samples. The results on the other catalyst systems will be reported elsewhere [21]. In the S. Velu, C.S. Swamy/Applied Catalysis A: General 145 (1996) 141-153 143 following sections, the copper-aluminium hydrotalcites are represented as CuA1 N.0-HT and their calcined samples (450 /8 h in air) are represented as CuA1 N.0-CHT where, 'N' is the Cu/A1 atomic ratio. For example, copper-aluminium hydrotalcite with Cu/A1 atomic ratio 3 will be represented as CuA1 3.0-HT and the corresponding calcined sample as CuA1 3.0-CHT. 2. Experimental Copper-aluminium hydrotalcite-like compounds with Cu/A1 atomic ratios of 2, 3 and 4 were synthesised by coprecipitation from a mixture of aqueous solutions with Cu(NO3)2 and AI(NO3)3 as precursors and a mixture of aqueous solutions of NaOH/Na2CO3 (CO2-/Cu + A1 = 20) as precipitant at room temperature and pH around 9. The resulting slurry was aged at 65/30 min. For comparison, copper-aluminium hydrotalcite-like compound with a Cu/A1 atomic ratio of 3 was prepared without giving any ageing treatment (abbreviated as CuA1 3.0-WAHT). For phase identification, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; Rigaku miniflex) was carried out using Fe-filtered CoK~ radiation (X = 1.7902 A) with a scan speed of 20 = 2min while a speed of 0.5min was used for the calculation of lattice parameters [22]. Elemental Si was used as an external standard. BET surface area, pore size distribution and pore volume study of calcined samples (450/8 h in air) was performed by N2 adsorption- desorption at 77 K using a Carlo Erba (Model 1800) sorptometer. The alkylation reactions were carried out with 1.5 g of calcined hydrotalcites (CHT) packed in a fixed bed flow reactor and a 1:7 phenol:methanol mixture was used as reactant feed with a space velocity, WHSV = 9.0 mol h-~ kg l (WHSV = weight hourly space velocity = flow rate of phenol (mol h-~)/weight of the catalyst (kg)). The phenolic products were condensed and collected in cold traps and analyzed using GC. The catalytic activity and product selectivity of these catalysts were compared with those of magnesium-aluminium calcined hydro- talcite with an Mg/A1 atomic ratio = 4 (MgA1 4.0-CHT), the most active catalyst for the phenol alkylation from our earlier report [13]. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Synthesis and characterization It is generally known that copper-aluminium hydrotalcites (CuA1-HT) are always mixed with other phases such as malachite or gerhardtite [23-25] due to the Jahn-Teller effect in the Cu2ion. An acceptable CuA1-HT has been prepared by decomposing a copper ammoniacal complex on ~/-A1203 in vacuum [26]. According to Reichle [27], CuA1-HT could only be made by using aqueous 144 S. Velu, C.S. The decomposition of cyclohex- anol over copper-aluminium calcined hydrotalcite (CuA1-CHT) showed pre- dominantly the dehydration activity indicating the presence of mainly acidic sites [28,29]. Furthermore, comparison of the selectivity of cyclohexene/cyclo- hexanone for samples A-D reveals that the variation of Cu/A1 atomic ratio or the ageing treatment does not influence the acid-base properties of these catalysts. These results are similar to those obtained over a series of MgA1-CHT (Mg/A1 atomic ratio 3-12) by the microcalorimetric determination of heat of adsorption of NH3 and CO2 [30]. In the present study, MgA1 4.0-CHT showed low dehydration activity indicating lower acidity or strong basicity of the sample. The acidity (Lewis type) in these catalysts is attributed to the dissolution of A13 + in the oxide lattice during calcination around 450 and coordinatively unsaturated 02- ion acting as a strong Lewis basic site [31,32]. 3.2. Catalytic studies 3.2.1. Effect of temperature The alkylation reactions were carried out in the temperature range 250-450. The effect of temperature on phenol conversion (Fig. 2) shows that MgA1 4.0-CHT (the most active catalyst reported in [13]) attained 100% phenol conversion at 400 itself, whereas CuA1-CHT attained only around 80% phenol conversion at 450. On the other hand, copper-aluminium hydrotalcite with a Cu/A1 atomic ratio of 3 obtained without ageing and calcined at 450/8 h in air (CuA13.0-WACHT) exhibited lowest activity indicating that the initial ageing of the slurry (65/30 min) is necessary for higher activity of these catalysts. Since the ageing treatment does not influence either the acid-base property or particle size or the surface area of the calcined sample, we presume that the malachite phase formed along with the HT phase in the aged sample enhances the catalytic activity. This is in accordance with the observation by Gusi et al. [33] in the low pressure methanol synthesis over the Cu-Zn-A1 catalyst. The effect of temperature on product selectivity over CuA13.0-CHT is shown in Fig. 3 which indicates that the selectivity of o-cresol declined while that of 2,6-xylenol and higher alkyl phenols increased with the increase in temperature. This could be due to the consecutive reactions of o-cresol to give 2,6-xylenol and higher alkyl phenols. The selectivity to anisole increased slightly (around 10%) in the temperature range 300-350 and then remained constant with further increase in temperature indicating that the secondary reactions of anisole are less favourable over these catalysts. 3.2.2. The optimum performance envelope (OPE) curves for the methylation of phenol over CuA1 3.0-CHT (Fig. 4) shows that anisole and o-cresol are primary alkylation products since both these products are formed at the onset of the reaction. The yield of anisole practically remained constant with the increase in phenol conversion while the yield of o-cresol passed a maximum around 40% conversion with consequent increase in the yield of 2,6-xylenol and higher alkyl phenols. These results indicate that o-cresol did undergo secondary reactions to give 2,6-xylenol and other higher alkyl phenols to a great extent. In order to verify these assumptions, reactions of anisole alone, an 1:7 mixture of anisole and methanol and 1:7 mixture of o-cresol and methanol were carried out over CuA1 3.0-CHT. When anisole alone was passed over CuA1 3.0-CHT, a large amount of phenol was noticed with a small quantity of o-cresol (Table 3). However, 2-methyl anisole was not observed in the temperature range 250-350 indicat- ing that anisole does not undergo a bimolecular reaction as observed previously over MgA1 4.0-CHT [13]. The formation of a large quantity of phenol is due to the dealkylation of anisole which can be attributed to the higher acidity [7] of CuA1 3.0-CHT compared to MgAI 4.0-CHT as evidenced from the higher cyclohexanol dehydration activity of the former (Table 2) [9,10]. The o-cresol may be formed through the monomolecular rearrangement of anisole. The formation of 2-methyl anisole at 400 could be due to the alkylation of o-cresol with anisole, since the activation of OH group in o-cresol is much easier compared to the activation of anisole [34]. Increase in contact time (WHSV = 13.5 mol h-1 kg-l) results in an increase in anisole conversion and the selectivity for 2,6-xylenol while the selectivity for phenol and o-cresol were not affected. However, the very low anisole conversion (~ 5% at 400C) substantiates that the reactions of anisole (inter/intra molecular) over these catalysts is less probable. The reaction of anisole with methanol (1:7) over CuA1 3.0-CHT (Table 4) demonstrates that anisole readily undergoes methylation to give 2-methyl anisole, o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol. When either the contact time (WHSV = 3.9 mol h- kg-1) or temperature is increased, the selectivity for o-cresol decreased with a consequent increase in the selectivity to 2,6-xylenol and higher alkyl phenols indicating that o-cresol is subsequently transformed into 2,6-xylenol and higher alkyl phenols. The reaction of a 1:7 mixture of o-cresol and methanol over the same catalyst (Table 5) shows that o-cresol effectively undergoes methylation to give 2,6- xylenol and higher alkyl phenols over these catalysts. Swamy/Applied Catalysis A: General 145 (1996) 141-153 In Fig. 5, the activity and selectivity for o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol at 400 over all the catalysts derived from CuA1-HT (Cu/A1 = 2, 3, 4) are compared with those of MgA1 4.0-CHT from our earlier report [13]. It can be seen that MgAI 4.0-CHT is the most active (nearly 100% phenol conversion) and more selective for 2,6-xylenol (around 60%). Substitution of Mg2+ by Cu2+ in the HT framework resulted in decrease in phenol conversion and increase in selectivity to o-cresol which follows the order CuA1 3.0-WACHT ~ CuA1 2.0-CHT > CuAI 3.0-CHT -- CuAI 4.0-CHT > MgA1 4.0-CHT. In order to get more insight into the selectivity pattern over these catalysts, the product selectivity was compared at constant phenol conversion levels (Fig. 6). At low phenol conversion (15-20%), MgA1 4.0-CHT gave maximum selectivity (nearly 100%) for anisole while it is very low (10-20%) over CuA1-CHT. The selectivity for o-cresol is in the order CuA1 3.0-CHT > CuA1 2.0-CHT > CuA1 3.0-WACHT ~ CuA1 4.0-CHT > > MgA1 4.0-CHT. At higher phenol conver- sions (45-55%) the selectivity for anisole decreases with consequent increase in selectivity for o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol over MgA1 4.0-CHT, whereas the selectivity for o-cresol decreases at the cost of 2,6-xylenol over CuA1-CHT. Furthermore, among the CuAI-CHT, there is no remarkable change in selectivity for o-cresol at higher phenol conversion indicating the presence of similar active sites in these catalysts. From these observations, it can be inferred that the alkylation reaction proceeds through the formation of anisole over MgA1-CHT which is due to the higher basicity of the catalysts, and on the other hand, by direct C-alkylation over CuA1-CHT which can be attributed to the higher acidic properties of these catalysts. 4. Conclusions (1) Pure and well crystalline copper aluminium hydrotalcite-like compounds without other phases such as malachite can be prepared by using a mixture of aqueous solutions of NaOH/Na2CO3 as precipitant. (2) MgA1-CHT was found to be a selective catalyst for the synthesis of 2,6-xylenol [13] and CuA1-CHT for o-cresol. (3) Owing to the higher basicity of MgA1-CHT, the o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol were formed mainly through anisole formation, and on the other hand, by direct C-alkylation over CuA1-CHT which is due to the higher acidity of catalysts. (4) The initial ageing treatment (65/30 rain) for CuA1-HT precursors was found to be important for higher phenol conversion and selectivity for o-cresol. (5) At low phenol conversion (15-20%) the selectivity for o-cresol decreases in the order CuA1 3.0-CHT > CuA1 2.0-CHT > CuA1 3.0-WACHT ~ CuA1 4.0-CHT > > MgA1 4.0-CHT while at higher phenol conversion it is similar for all the CuA1-CHT. (+91-44) 2350509 Copper aluminium hydrotalcites (CuAl-HT) with a Cu/Al atomic ratio of 2, 3 and 4 (CuAl 2.0-HT, CuAl 3.0-HT, CuAl 4.0-HT) were synthesised by the coprecipitation method using a mixture of NaOH/Na2CO3 as precipitant. The pure crystalline hydrotalcite (HT) phase was detected by X-ray diffraction when the copper-aluminium hydrotalcite was prepared without ageing (CuAl 3.0-WAHT). Vapour phase alkylation of phenol with methanol was carried out over CuAl-HT calcined at 450°C/8 h in air (CuAl-CHT). The activity and selectivity of these catalysts were compared with those of magnesium-aluminium calcined hydrotalcites (MgAl 4.0-CHT) from our earlier report. MgAl 4.0-CHT showed higher selectivity for 2,6-xylenol whereas CuAl-CHT was selective for o-cresol. Among the CuAl-CHT studied, CuAl 3.0-CHT showed higher phenol conversion at low temperatures (250–350°C). The catalyst derived from pure copper-aluminium hydrotalcite (CuAl 3.0-WACHT) showed lowest phenol conversion compared to other copper based catalysts obtained from a mixture of HT and malachite phases. The selectivity for o-cresol decreased in the order CuAl 3.0-CHT > CuAl 2.0-CHT > CuAl 3.0-WACHT ≈ CuAl 4.0-CHT > MgAl 4.0-CHT at low phenol conversion levels (15–20%). A suitable reaction pathway for the alkylation of phenol with methanol over these catalysts has been proposed after a careful examination of the reaction sequence. The selective C-alkylation to give o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol over CuAl-CHT could be attributed to the higher acidity of these catalysts as evidenced by the higher cyclohexanol dehydration activity.
